1.rationale:
Looking at the board, the nearest apple is at a position of (6, 4). I think the best strategy would be to head towards the nearest apple as the first priority in order to grow the length of my snake and gain more points. There are no walls in the way to the nearest apple and I also need to take into account the position of the enemy snake which is at a position of (9, 2). The enemy snake is to the right and slightly above my current position. However, since it is not directly in my path, I can ignore it for now and focus on reaching the apple.

A shorter path to reach the apple located at (6, 4) from my current position of (4, 1) would be to first go up, then right. So, for this turn, I will go up and on the next turn, I will go right towards the apple.

Next move: UP

2.rationale:
Thinking out loud:
Our snake (ID 2) is at (9,2) and the closest apple is at (6,4) with a Manhattan distance of 5. From (9,2) we can either go UP or LEFT since both moves reduce the distance:
• Moving LEFT takes us to (8,2) which gives a remaining distance of |8–6| + |2–4| = 2 + 2 = 4.
• Moving UP takes us to (9,3) which gives a remaining distance of |9–6| + |3–4| = 3 + 1 = 4.
Both moves are safe and within board boundaries, and neither risks a collision with our enemy snake at (4,1) or with any walls.

I favor moving LEFT right away to start reducing the horizontal gap toward the apple at (6,4) while keeping safe distance.

Decided move: LEFT
